questions.question_text:
After seeing the planned features for an upcoming release, a customer notes that a vitally important and complex one is missing. The team estimates that this feature significantly exceeds its average velocity.
How can this issue be resolved?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
In this situation, the best approach would be to break down the feature into smaller parts, and commit to completing the minimum viable product (Option A). Here’s why:

Incremental Delivery: By breaking down the feature into smaller, manageable parts, the team can deliver incremental value to the customer while working towards the complete feature.
Prioritization: This approach allows the team to prioritize the most critical aspects of the feature, ensuring that the most important functionality is delivered first.
Flexibility: It provides flexibility to adapt and make adjustments based on feedback and progress, rather than committing to an all-or-nothing approach.
This method aligns with agile principles of iterative development and continuous delivery of value.

If the team suggests changes that could add significant value but also require extra work, the agile project leader should consult the product owner. questions.question_text: Why should an agile coach model agile principles and behaviours, become self-aware, and be present?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The best reason for an agile coach to model agile principles and behaviors, become self-aware, and be present is to better listen, serve, and help the team grow their strengths individually and as a team (Option A). Here’s why:

Servant Leadership: Agile coaches embody the role of servant leaders, focusing on the growth and well-being of the team members and helping them achieve their full potential.
Empowerment: By listening and serving, the coach empowers the team to take ownership of their work and make decisions that drive continuous improvement.
Strengthening Team Dynamics: This approach fosters a supportive environment where team members feel valued and motivated, leading to stronger collaboration and better overall performance.
While understanding team dynamics and developing a high-performing team (Option D) is also important, it is a result of the coach’s ability to listen, serve, and help the team grow.

questions.question_text:
There is a database feature requiring three members of a seven person team. A meeting is scheduled at the beginning of the sprint to go over technical needs to complete the story.
Who should the Scrum Master invite to the meeting?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In this scenario, the Scrum Master should invite the core team and the product owner (Option D). Here’s why:

Core Team Involvement: The core team members who will be working on the database feature need to understand the technical requirements and collaborate on the implementation plan.
Product Owner’s Role: The product owner provides the necessary context and ensures that the technical needs align with the overall product vision and priorities.
This combination ensures that both the technical and business perspectives are covered, facilitating a comprehensive discussion and effective planning.
